title: Tower Moment in Tarot: What it Means & How to Handle It

steps.title: A “tower moment” is a period of sudden change, chaos, or upheaval.
steps.content: A “tower moment” is a period of sudden change, chaos, or upheaval. The term comes from the Tower card in the tarot deck, and it’s a common phrase among tarot readers. When you’re going through a tower moment, something in your life has been built on a shaky foundation, and it’s likely to come crashing down. An unexpected breakup, suddenly losing your job, or a major falling-out with a friend could all be tower moments. [1] X Research source This unexpected change may feel like a disaster at first, but it’s also necessary. The destruction clears the way for positive growth and transformation, allowing you to become the person you’re meant to be. [2] X Research source

steps.title: The Tower card represents unexpected disaster.
steps.content: The Tower card represents unexpected disaster. It's in the Major Arcana (the first 22 cards of the tarot), meaning it deals with major life events and overarching themes. [3] X Research source The traditional Rider-Waite deck illustration depicts a tower being struck by lightning. The lightning sets the tower ablaze, and people jump out of the windows to escape the flames. The tower had seemed to be strong and solid, but it sits on a shaky foundation, so it comes crumbling down with one lightning strike. [4] X Research source If you’re doing a tarot reading and draw the Tower upright, the card serves as a heads-up that a major life change could be coming your way. This change might seem like a catastrophe, but the Tower card suggests that it’s actually for your good. In the wake of the chaos and destruction, you’ll realize what aspects of your life were built on a shaky foundation, leaving you room to rebuild stronger and better. [5] X Research source Drawn reversed, the Tower may be letting you know that you have time to avert disaster. If something feels off in your life, trust your intuition and act quickly. You may be able to address things before you’re forced to go through your tower moment. [6] X Research source In a Yes or No tarot reading, the Tower card means “no.” [7] X Research source

steps.title: Embrace change.
steps.content: Embrace change. Change is inevitable, and learning to deal with change can help you get through a tower moment. [8] X Research source When things start to come crumbling down, focus your energy one what you’ll do to rebuild, rather than trying to keep things from falling apart. Letting go of something familiar can be scary, but it also clears the way for you to build up something better. [9] X Research source If you’re struggling to embrace change, try reframing. This involves shifting your perspective to focus on the positive in a situation, rather than the negative, which can help you manage difficult emotions. [10] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source For example, instead of thinking of your tower moment as a disaster, try to see it as an opportunity to grow. Ask yourself what this chaotic period is trying to teach you, and trust that the universe is looking out for you.

steps.title: Practice self-care.
steps.content: Practice self-care. The chaos of a tower moment can definitely be overwhelming. [11] X Research source In the midst of this period of upheaval, prioritizing self-care is especially important. Be kind to yourself as you navigate this period of change and upheaval—you’re doing the best you can! If you’re feeling especially run-down, treat yourself to a relaxing bubble bath or a cozy night in to unwind. You could also try going on a hike or taking a sunrise yoga class to spend some time in nature.

steps.title: Practice mindfulness.
steps.content: Practice mindfulness. A tower moment requires you to let go of your old ideas and plans, trusting that this upheaval will lead to a better future. [12] X Research source Practicing mindfulness can be helpful in this situation because it involves focusing intensely on the present moment. Plus, mindfulness can help reduce anxious or depressed feelings, which can be common during tower moments. [13] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source To get started with a mindful lifestyle, try out mindful meditation . Sit down in a quiet place and focus on the sensations you’re experiencing. Feel the flow of your breath, and let any thoughts that come up pass without judgment. [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Lean on your loved ones.
steps.content: Lean on your loved ones. While you’re going through your tower moment, it’s important to surround yourself with people you love and trust. Remember, you don’t have to go it alone. Reach out to your support system, and don’t be afraid to lean on them during this tough time. Social connection can help promote your physical and emotional wellbeing as you navigate your tower moment. In fact, increased social connection has been shown to decrease stress and anxiety, as well as improve sleep quality. [15] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Talk things out with a therapist.
steps.content: Talk things out with a therapist. Big life changes can be incredibly difficult to navigate. If you’re experiencing symptoms of anxiety or depression during your tower moment, you’re not alone! Consider talking to a licensed therapist or counselor to help you cope . They can provide you with a safe space to work through your feelings and plan for the future, so you can come back from your tower moment better than ever. Ask a trusted friend or family member for a referral if they work with a therapist, or check out online directories to choose the right therapist for you.
